Week 4 The Iron Yard

Posted by Joey F. Poon on May 31, 2015

Bittersweet

Itâ€™s the end of my 4th week at TIY and itâ€™s a strange feeling. Weâ€™ve gone from variables and arrays on day 1 to creating dynamic pages with Rails in less than 20 class days. With a third of the program now complete, Iâ€™m excited about what more Iâ€™ll be able to do at the end of the whole program. At the same time, Iâ€™m sad to see time passing so quickly. These 4 weeks have been the busiest and yet the most rewarding weeks of my life. Itâ€™s a bittersweet feeling. Oh, and I did eventually finish our week 3 lab.

Monday

Memorial day, no class ðŸ˜¢.

Tuesday

Crazy rain caused some ridiculous flooding and freeways were all closed. Needless to say, TIY was closed too ðŸ˜¢.

Wednesday

Yay class! I have been so excited for this week to come. Itâ€™s Rails week! But before that, challenge. Nothing too fancy today, just a bit of CSS positioning practice.

Lecture today is onâ€¦Rails! Bet you didnâ€™t see that coming! So excite, much knowledge. Jesse did a quick run through of a basic Rails app with static pages.

rails new app_name
rails g controller Pages action1 action2
rails s

He talked us through a simple Texas Cities site. During the walkthrough, he also went over routes, the gemfile, and the asset pipeline. No models yet.

After lunch, we had a review and Jesse ended up doing another talk-through of a superhero static pages app.

Homework is to create a basic Rails app with some pages. I made mine about animals gifs because why not.

Thursday

Todayâ€™s challenge is some Ruby class review. The interesting thing about this challenge is the introduction of class Date to help us get the age of a person. I have to admit that I got a little cocky when I read challenge. Date.today.year - @dob.year, ezpz right? Nope. Doesnâ€™t pass the test because I forgot to account for whether the birthday has already passed or not for the current year. I was eventually able to come up with this as a solution. Iâ€™m pretty sure this solution doesnâ€™t account for leap years and leap birthdays but our 15 minutes were up ðŸ˜ž.

Whatâ€™s not static? Thatâ€™s right, dynamic! Todayâ€™s lecture is on dynamic pages in Rails. Jesse took our static Texas cities app from yesterday and turned it into an app with dynamic pages. Dynamic pages are way cool. We basically deleted all of our views from the static example and were able to make a single view with changing content. This allows us to generate millions of pages for different products, like Amazon does, with just a handful of views. Dynamic routes are awesome too get '/:post_name' => 'pages#show', as: :post .

This is day 2 of the week but it is still Thursday so of course we still get a lab ðŸ˜€. We basically have to take our week 3 lab and turn it into a Rails app with dynamic pages.

Friday

Our guest speaker for the week is Roby Fitzhenry. Roby is a self-made entrepreneur and designer who speaks with passion. He shared his personal story with us and inspired us to follow our passion. One especially interesting moment to me was when someone asked Roby about front end vs back end pay. Robyâ€™s response was that you should do whatever you enjoy. If you enjoy it, youâ€™ll keep doing it and eventually youâ€™ll become great at it.

Roby also explained design in a very human way, simply as a narrative. The most important thing is the story that you are telling. I think that as someone who loves banging away at the keyboard to chip away at technical problems, I sometimes forget what the end goal is. That is that I am building products for humans. How I build and design my applications tell a story to my users. How the story is told is just as important as the story itself. rambling.end

So I actually finished the lab this week early and submitted it Thursday evening. Jesse, being the awesome instructor that he is, added nightmare mode Friday morning and made a point to let me know. You have to love it when an instructor adjusts for his students ðŸ˜€. Since weâ€™re doing Rails now, Iâ€™ll start adding both production and code links for Rails apps that I deploy. Week 4 lab: production | code. Itâ€™s not really mobile responsive yet but I do plan on adding that in soon.

Closing Thoughts

Rails is awesome. Small things like .parameterize and .pluralize really make Rails friendly to use. Ruby and Rails might not be the leanest but the ease of use makes it such a joy to program with. In the end, isnâ€™t that what technology is for? To make life easier? Itâ€™s exciting to see how far weâ€™ve come in 4 weeks and I definitely canâ€™t wait to see what weâ€™ll be able to produce by the end of 12 weeks. Next week is database stuff, canâ€™t wait!
